AMD4EVER

http://www.cnn.com/2004/WORLD/asiapcf/auspac/01/12/aust.missile/index.html
 
 Australia is working to set up a ballistic missile defense and that in itself worries some nuclear powers such as China since having a ballistic missile defense would render their nuclear missile pointless. However the benefits to such a system are that rouge nations like North Korea wouldn't be able to easily attack other countries with nuclear weapons. This would also reduce the possibility of the world ending in one horrible nuclear war if the major powers did have some sort of ballistic missile defense.
 
 So do you think China is right in protesting that such a system be put into place or do you think Australia is right in trying to create such a system?
mamboni

Personally, I don't see anything wrong with the implementation of this, but they shouldn't do it conspicuously. Try to be a bit subtle about it as to prevent arousing chaotic ordeals and debates from other countries.
 Of course, that may not even be feasible or possible. But I can see this encouraging an arms race and proliferating nuclear weapons and their buildups.
AMD4EVER

Personally, I don't see anything wrong with the implementation of this, but they shouldn't do it conspicuously. Try to be a bit subtle about it as to prevent arousing chaotic ordeals and debates from other countries.
 Of course, that may not even be feasible or possible. But I can see this encouraging an arms race and proliferating nuclear weapons and their buildups.

 
 What type of arms race can you see growing out of this? Personally I can only see countries feverishly trying to develop their own ballistic missile defense after one country succeeds at it and that in itself will help prevent any new offensive arms race. Why do you think countries will begin building up more nuclear weapons just as they are becoming obsolete?
Toxey

What type of arms race can you see growing out of this? Personally I can only see countries feverishly trying to develop their own ballistic missile defense after one country succeeds at it and that in itself will help prevent any new offensive arms race. Why do you think countries will begin building up more nuclear weapons just as they are becoming obsolete?

 
 
 A ballistic missile defense system can only handle so many missles coming at it a the same time.Therefore other countries might up their production of missles to defeat another countries ballistic missile defense.
AMD4EVER

A ballistic missile defense system can only handle so many missles coming at it a the same time.Therefore other countries might up their production of missles to defeat another countries ballistic missile defense.

 
 Honestly, why would that occur? First off building up more offensive weapons leads to building up of more defensive weapons. Considering that the defensive weapons cancel out the offensive weapons meaning that the country creating the offensive weapons can never even use their weapons while the defensive countries can make perfect use of theirs any time it is necessary to do so, what would be the point of trying to build offensive weapons? They would be a waste of money that would accomplish nothing. If anything I would think that countries would go nuts creating defensive weapons. I'm sure countries like the US and China wouldn't settle for just doing one or the other but most countries would probably prefer to have a defensives weapon the makes them look peaceful and can protect them than an offensive one that makes them look aggressive and will fail if used.
mamboni

What type of arms race can you see growing out of this? Personally I can only see countries feverishly trying to develop their own ballistic missile defense after one country succeeds at it and that in itself will help prevent any new offensive arms race. Why do you think countries will begin building up more nuclear weapons just as they are becoming obsolete?

 
 
 To me, the installation of ballistic missile defense is sort of an in-your-face thing. I can see competition coming out of this, and tensions can escalate. 
 Building up a strong defense may encourage other nations, whom already loathe the said country installing ballistics, to produce new weapons with technology capable of bypassing the defense missiles. 
 In other words, if a country's rival sets up defenses, you better be damn sure the opposite side is going to work on it's offense.
AMD4EVER

To me, the installation of ballistic missile defense is sort of an in-your-face thing. I can see competition coming out of this, and tensions can escalate. 
 Building up a strong defense may encourage other nations, whom already loathe the said country installing ballistics, to produce new weapons with technology capable of bypassing the defense missiles. 
 In other words, if a country's rival sets up defenses, you better be damn sure the opposite side is going to work on it's offense.

 
 Lets take Australia v China for instance. China has some 600 nuclear weapons and Australia has nothing and know they can never make nuclear weapons as the rest of the world would not accept it. Talk about in your face, China is a constant threat to them and Australia is bound from doing anything. So using your own logic you have to believe Australia should create defensive weapons in response to this in your face tactic.
 
 So Australia creates a defensive array to protect themselves from nuclear weapons and pledges to protect any one of their allies from nuclear missiles launched from China. Now China has an obsolete nuclear missile program while their enemies can strike them with nuclear missiles at any given time. China would have two options, either create their own defensive network or try and create weapons that can bypass the current defensive curtain hanging over them. They can be certain that within a given period of time that they can develop a network similar to that of Australia and even the playing field by making themselves safe from nuclear attack or they can try and develop a weapon that currently doesn't exist and surely would cost a great deal of money and time to create while still leaving them completely open to nuclear attack. Logically China would choose the defensive option first just as a way to get rid of their main weakness.
 
 I think the world would see a massive build up of defensive weapons, especially by countries like Iran, Israel, Pakistan, India, Japan, Taiwan, Australia, US, EU, Russia, and China. These are all countries that are either top on someones to kill list or countries that simply don't have the offensive option and need to build a credible defense. This massive worldwide build up of defensive weapons would occur at a pace much faster than the build up of new offensive weapons because of how practical defensive weapons would be compared to offensive weapons. China simply could not stand by next to a US that has 20x more nuclear missiles than them as well as a nuclear shield over them. China would have to build a defensive shield of their own or risk falling to an aggressive US without being able to get a chance to fight.
 
 Of course their will be consequences to this defensive build up. Missiles and bombs of old will become useless as weapons and offensive weapons will probably have to get a lot smaller to be effective. Chemical and germ warfare, laser warfare, technological sabotage, and nanotech warfare would be the future. It may even create more wars based on the knowledge that their were 2 world wars before nuclear weapons and none since. So it is possible that things could go bad. On the other side of the coin I see that we have never really needed to worry about a countries defense as much as their offense. With offense being more powerful than defense it is really an invetation to war. If it is the other way around then war becomes infeasible and won't occur. So if defensive weapons take presidence and organizations like the UN, who wish for stability, try to keep it that way using their own influence, that could mean the end to major conflicts.
 
 There are many ways this could go if Australia builds a defensive shield but I think it is certain that allowing countries who cannot produce nuclear weapons to produce a defensive shield makes perfect sense. They have a right to protect themselves and just as China is able to do so through fear of nuclear attacks Australia should be able to by being able to defend themselves from nuclear attacks.
mamboni

Great argument, I'm learning a lot..
 I had no idea China was in possession of so many nukes. I thought it was about two-hundred and fifty, how woefully misinformed I was. emoticon_emb
AMD4EVER

Great argument, I'm learning a lot..
 I had no idea China was in possession of so many nukes. I thought it was about two-hundred and fifty, how woefully misinformed I was. emoticon_emb

 
 http://www.nrdc.org/nuclear/nudb/datab19.asp
 
 According to this website China probably has about 400 nuclear weapons in 2002 but because of the secrecy of the Chinese government no real confirmation can be made as to how many nuclear weapons China has. The site gives a possible error of +-50%. My estimate of 600 Chinese nukes is giving China the benefit of the doubt and assuming there is an error of +50%. China may have as few nuclear weapons as 300 or even less as they have been dismantling some weapons recently.
mamboni

http://www.nrdc.org/nuclear/nudb/datab19.asp
 
 According to this website China probably has about 400 nuclear weapons in 2002 but because of the secrecy of the Chinese government no real confirmation can be made as to how many nuclear weapons China has. The site gives a possible error of +-50%. My estimate of 600 Chinese nukes is giving China the benefit of the doubt and assuming there is an error of +50%. China may have as few nuclear weapons as 300 or even less as they have been dismantling some weapons recently.

 
 Hm, that's interesting. It's also interesting to observe how the numbers climbed so substantially throughout the duration of the Cold War. But also very perturbing.
Broker

Note that Russia actually has about 30,000 nuclear weapons. 20,000 are "awaiting dismantlement," meaning they still exist... but I wouldn't say more than a third or Russia's nuclear weapons work anyway. :X
Toxey

Honestly, why would that occur? First off building up more offensive weapons leads to building up of more defensive weapons. Considering that the defensive weapons cancel out the offensive weapons meaning that the country creating the offensive weapons can never even use their weapons while the defensive countries can make perfect use of theirs any time it is necessary to do so, what would be the point of trying to build offensive weapons? They would be a waste of money that would accomplish nothing. If anything I would think that countries would go nuts creating defensive weapons. I'm sure countries like the US and China wouldn't settle for just doing one or the other but most countries would probably prefer to have a defensives weapon the makes them look peaceful and can protect them than an offensive one that makes them look aggressive and will fail if used.

 
 Dont get me wrong,,I am all for ballistic missile defense.But you was asking what type of arms race would occur.
 I know good and well any country with this type of defense will implement it as soon as its up and going.But I also know good and well it wont be 100% as soon as its rolling.The system will only be able to handle so many missiles at one time.Therefore to make up for the defense system other countries will up production of nukes on a missile.
AMD4EVER

Dont get me wrong,,I am all for ballistic missile defense.But you was asking what type of arms race would occur.
 I know good and well any country with this type of defense will implement it as soon as its up and going.But I also know good and well it wont be 100% as soon as its rolling.The system will only be able to handle so many missiles at one time.Therefore to make up for the defense system other countries will up production of nukes on a missile.

 
 Lets take the Australia v China example again then. Lets say China has 600 nukes and Australias system can handle 3 at a time and will be able to handle 600 at a time 3 years from now. So using your theory China will start mass producing nuclear weapons. Now it is 3 years later. China has 3,000 nukes and Australia can handle 600 nukes. However the US now has a system that can handle 2,000 nukes and other Australian allies can handle 400. So here China is 3 years later with billions of dollars spent in creating nuclear missiles and they are now totally ineffective because of the Australian's and their allies. Good money spent by the Australian's while China just wasted a bunch of money and still has to spend some money to make their own nuclear shield.
 
 Let me know if it seems like I am missing something here but it would seem to me that eventually there will be a global nuclear shield up within just a few years after one country gets a defense system in place making it pointless to build more nukes unless you are planning on using them very soon. Also note it is stupid to use nukes just before a nuclear shield goes up because you will inevitably pay for it later. For instance lets say China uses nukes on Australia, Japan, and Taiwan 3 years before the nuclear shield goes up. 3 years go by and by this time the entire world is at war and the shield is up and running and only protecting those who oppose China. China gets nuked over and over and can not do anything about it. They inevitably surrender and lose everything.
 
 I just can't see why there would be a nuclear arms race for any reason if countries start developing nuclear defenses.
Robbie

I can definately see an arms race. In particular in improving missiles in stealtiness and speed. Also in setting up the defenses. 
 
 The same sort of thing can be seen historically in the change of aircraft bombers vs. the defences set up against them. I'm sure that many defensive developments looked as if they would kill the ability of aircraft to enter enemy space, but we still have bombers.
 
 For example, as radar got much stronger, aircraft started flying very low to the ground to hide from the ground based radar using terrain and the natural curvature of the earth. Then, air-based radar was developed, which could look downwards and pick up the low-flying planes. Aircraft development shifted to flying too high to be intercepted. (U-2 and SR-71) 
 Now, stealth has basically put us back where we started.
 
 Another example is castles. (very rough historical sketch!) Earlier ones were very effective at defending. Then siege development improved and things like trebuchets could tear them down. Castles improved to the point where trebuchets were completely ineffective. Then, gunpowder, and now castles are obsolete.
 
 The point is, don't think that offensive weapons will become obsolete. They may for a while, but its not likely to hold.
 
 However, I think I support the defensive shields. 
 
 My objection is that another arms race will take money away from needy people, and I think that is a serious consideration.
AMD4EVER

The point is, don't think that offensive weapons will become obsolete. They may for a while, but its not likely to hold.
 
 However, I think I support the defensive shields. 
 
 My objection is that another arms race will take money away from needy people, and I think that is a serious consideration.

 
 I don't see offensive weapons going obsolete either but look at what we have right now. Even the most backwards country can develop nuclear weapons and even the most advanced country has no way of defending themselves from nuclear attack. If we had a defensive array in place it would at least prevent nuclear weapons from being the end all be all. We would have some sort of balance and places like the United States couldn't be threatened by rogue nations like North Korea because of their ability to develop a nuclear bomb.
 
 I also wonder what type of arms race we would really see. First off I think we would see a massive build up of a worldwide defensive net. That in itself is a major step towards peace. Without the threat of nuclear weapons we no longer have to fear countries who have nothing to lose like North Korea starting a world war. Then we are back to only the major players being in control of wars and of course each of them has something to lose by starting a war. Even if we are all able to develop newer and better weapons that can defeat our own defenses at least the rogue nations will not be able to do so as well and that is a good thing for peace. As for cost, I think the lost of Los Angeles would be greater than that of building an entire nuclear net at the end of the day.
treat2

Nothing but a waste of money. Let 1 MIRV through, and how many cities are
 wasted. Just do the math using any number of missles and even a "shield" with a decent hit ratio will let through dozens of nukes from a MIRV.
 
 "Shield" is a misnomer. Besides which, a rogue nation would almost certainly ship the stuff over in a crate, and have it already planted anywhere they wanted to.

post_info.post_title: Nothing but a waste of money

AMD4EVER

Nothing but a waste of money. Let 1 MIRV through, and how many cities are
 wasted. Just do the math using any number of missles and even a "shield" with a decent hit ratio will let through dozens of nukes from a MIRV.

 
 So your theory is that it is just as well that 600 nukes fall on us rather than wasting our money on a defense system and having 100 fall on us instead? Uhhh, needless to say I don't agree with you at all. Not only would the defense network save lives, it would also protect the environment and lessen the impact that nuclear winter, nuclear fallout, and the amount of radioactive areas. Furthermore it would be a major deterant to using nuclear weapons.
 
 
"Shield" is a misnomer. Besides which, a rogue nation would almost certainly ship the stuff over in a crate, and have it already planted anywhere they wanted to.

 
 First off lets compare shipping a nuke to launching one. With shipping a nuke we do have a first line of defense and have a chance of preventing it from arriving in the first place. With launching a nuke we have no defense at this time. Secondly the size of the nukes shipped will have to be smaller than one that can be launched. And finally nukes that are shipped will have to be detonated from low altitudes meaning they will do substancially less damage than one that is launched. Again needless to say, I'd rather have rogue nations trying to ship nukes here than feeling free to launch them here.
Void

The problem is that defensive-missile technology is easily rendered completely ineffective.
 
 It is very hard to hit a moving missile in flight, especially if that missile is also coming in from outside the atmosphere. It is also very easy to modify offensive missiles to trick the defensive missiles. 
 
 An enemy with 1 nuclear warhead can get it past a defense system of 10 defense missiles very easily. All they would have to do is create 50 missiles and plant their nuke in just one of them.
 
 We would see 50 missiles coming our way. Even if we knew 49 of them were actually dummies, we wouldn't know which one was the live nuke. Even if our 10 defense missiles have 100% efficiency we can only take down 10 of the 50 incoming missiles. There is an 80% chance we will pick the wrong ones and the nuke will get through.
 
 In terms of money, the Star Wars defense system then becomes a complete waste. If all countries like China have to do to get past our defense shield is build dummy missiles, then they will outprice us. That is, if we continue trying to build more defense missiles, they will build more dummy missiles. Dummy missiles will cost so much less than defensive missiles that we will risk destabilising the economy by attempting to keep up.
 
 This also doesn't take into account other techniques the enemy could use such as equipting missiles with flares to detour incoming defense missiles. If they can reduce the efficiency of the missiles, we will require more of them and yet again we will be spending more money.
 
 If we continued such an arms race we would go bankrupt just like the soviet union did.
AMD4EVER

The problem is that defensive-missile technology is easily rendered completely ineffective.
 
 It is very hard to hit a moving missile in flight, especially if that missile is also coming in from outside the atmosphere. It is also very easy to modify offensive missiles to trick the defensive missiles. 
 
 An enemy with 1 nuclear warhead can get it past a defense system of 10 defense missiles very easily. All they would have to do is create 50 missiles and plant their nuke in just one of them.
 
 We would see 50 missiles coming our way. Even if we knew 49 of them were actually dummies, we wouldn't know which one was the live nuke. Even if our 10 defense missiles have 100% efficiency we can only take down 10 of the 50 incoming missiles. There is an 80% chance we will pick the wrong ones and the nuke will get through.

 
 I agree with this as far as it concerns missiles. Defensive missiles simply will not do in the long run because of the reasons you listed here. Sure they are effective in picking off missiles which are going in a straight line as well as those which are just being launched but they cannot deal with multiple targets nor can they deal well with evasive missiles. A missile based defense would have it's place but it will not be an effective way of creating a worldwide missile shield. The best solution is one that we have yet to near perfecting and that is laser based. The US has been tinkering with laser based missile defense for years now and has only shown limited success. They have already succeeded in shooting down two simulated nuclear missiles within a matter of seconds but they have failed far more than that and the laser is bluky, expensive, and takes time to power up. Advances will have to be made in this field to create a truely effective missile defense. Still I would debate that having a missile based system for now is a great deterent to nuclear attacks and it will save lives either through deterence or by shooting down missiles. It is a far better solution than what we currently have which is Mutually Assured Destruction.
 
 
In terms of money, the Star Wars defense system then becomes a complete waste. If all countries like China have to do to get past our defense shield is build dummy missiles, then they will outprice us. That is, if we continue trying to build more defense missiles, they will build more dummy missiles. Dummy missiles will cost so much less than defensive missiles that we will risk destabilising the economy by attempting to keep up.

 
 You make a good point here. The strategy of using dummy missiles would be an effective way to get around our defense. It would be a cost effective way to beat the system for a country like China or any other major country. The only question to be posed then is would China actually attempt to use this type of strategy. First lets assume China wanted to attack the US with nuclear weapons. They have to assume that a massive attack by them would be answered back with a equal or greater force. They have only 600 nukes to our 9,000. They would have no choice but to launch in great numbers in order to break the shield which would ensure that they be retaliated against by thousands of nuclear weapons of which none will be shot down while the US may shoot some of theirs down. So China would be left with two choices. Either a full nuclear attack and get blown away or no attack at all. This would limit China to only going to nuclear war if they were prepared to be totally eliminated unlike is the case today where they could launch a single nuke and take out a Los Angeles and expect only a few nukes back at them. It eliminates the likelihood of China using nuclear weapons even in a major conflict as they would have to go all out or face inevitable failure.
 
 Although I think that is a nice perk to this system, as I said before I am more interested in this system to prevent rogue nations from becoming nuclear threats than I am concerned about superpowers going nuclear. As it stands today I don't see it as very likely that a superpower will engage in a nuclear war because defeat would be inevitable for both sides. I would also debate that the closest anyone has ever come to launching a nuclear missile was Cuba because they simply had nothing to lose. Those are the real threats and this shield would take care of them for the most part.
 
 
This also doesn't take into account other techniques the enemy could use such as equipting missiles with flares to detour incoming defense missiles. If they can reduce the efficiency of the missiles, we will require more of them and yet again we will be spending more money.
 
 If we continued such an arms race we would go bankrupt just like the soviet union did.

 
 I don't think that a shield would end up depending totally on missiles otherwise there would be too many ways to defeat it. Also if the US set out to make this shield by themselves then you could debate they could go bankrupt but if this became a project which was carried out cooperatively by many countries throughout the world then it would lessen the burden while making it more likely that every country will support the idea of this shield. This in itself would promote peace and unity.
Void

It is a far better solution than what we currently have which is Mutually Assured Destruction.
 
 Mutually assured destruction prevented the cold war turning into world war 3. It has prevented the world's superpowers waging war on each other during the last 50 years. You point this out yourself whe you mention that China would never launch nuclear weapons at the US due to the nuclear arms the US has. This also counts for convential war too, China is never even going to consider a full out conventional attack and invasion of the US because they know that even if they can win the conventional war, the US will retaliate against their country with nukes and ultimately noone will win.
 
 If you start making missile shields that work, then other countries such as China will also start making them. It might seem a world under a nuclear shield would be a paradise without threat from nuclear world war, but it wouldn't be. As soon as the nuclear blanket is put in place, militaries around the world would start gearing up for conventional warfare on a huge scale. 
 
 It is my opinion that the drive for a nuclear defense shield is soley because North Korea will soon possess nuclear weapons and the missiles to carry them. They will of course continue building more nukes if they think their deterent is ineffective. I can only imagine then that he star wars project is simply a way of sinking NK into extreme debt and collapse by triggering an arms race with them
 
 Also lasers in space is a nice idea but they can be dual use. If the US starts putting up defense lasers into space then countries like China will too. Under this blanket of "defense" all sorts of military weapons could be placed in space (if they aren't already there!)
AMD4EVER

It is a far better solution than what we currently have which is Mutually Assured Destruction.

 
 As I also said, MAD is all well and good and it prevented the US and Russia from wanting to launch nuclear weapons. However it didn't prevent Cuba from wanting to launch nuclear weapons at the US. There is of course a reason for that and that is the US and Russia had a whole lot more to lose than Cuba did. Cuba is like North Korea is like Iran is like the terrorists. They have far less to lose than the China's and US's of the world. I forget where I heard this quote but it really does ring true, "It isn't the guy with 1,000 nukes that I'm worried about, it is the guy with 1". MAD will prevent the US and China from going to war but it won't stop Osama or North Korea from using nuclear weapons. The governments are just too unstable in those countries/organizations to really have MAD play a preventative role in starting a nuclear war. If we had a defensive shield up it would be an added layer of defense to prevent terrorists or rogue nations from being able to start an internation conflict far greater than the incident that started WWI.
